Award.AwardTitle: Sequence Requirements for Small RNA Targeting in Plants

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Every cell in a given organism contains exactly the same DNA genome, yet the organism contains many cell types that are differentiated and highly specialized for certain functions. The functional differences between various cell types with the same genome are dictated by the subset of DNA-encoded genes that are activated (turned on) or silenced (turned off). The control of gene expression (on or off) thus plays a fundamental role in shaping cellular function in complex organisms. One type of gene expression control mechanism is directed by small regulatory RNAs. Small RNAs function to identify target RNAs in the cell by RNA-RNA complementarity. Essentially, if a given small RNA has a good match in sequence to a given target RNA, that target RNA will be prevented from being utilized further, and expression of the target gene will be turned off. Small RNA-based methods of gene expression control are prominent in plants, play important roles in normal plant growth and agricultural productivity, and can be exploited in biotechnological applications where control of gene expression is desirable. This project is seeking to understand the rules by which small RNAs recognize their targets in plants. The project specifically will examine the extent and configuration of matching RNA bases required to allow small RNAs to recognize and regulate their targets in plants. The outcome of this project will be a much more complete understanding of how the small RNA-mediated gene expression system is able to discriminate its handful of target RNAs from the thousands of non-target RNAs present in the cell.

Broader Impacts: Small RNAs are known to control key aspects of plant growth development, many of them with agricultural significance in crop plants. Small RNAs also dictate the repression of vast portions of plant genomes comprised of parasitic, so-called junk DNA. Manipulation of small RNAs already plays a key role in many plant biotechnology applications, but without a thorough understanding of how small RNAs work, these applications are limited. The understanding of small RNA target identification provided by this project should enhance such applications. This project also involves training of scientists, a critical national goal, both at the Ph.D. level and undergraduate level. One of the project goals will be used as a springboard for developing a new laboratory course in RNA Biology at Pennsylvania State University, thus enhancing scientific literacy and education of these students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The control of gene expression is a fundamental problem in the life sciences. Genes are discrete regions of a DNA molecule that are functional in some way. In most cases, genes are transcribed (an RNA is generated using the sequence of bases on the DNA as a template), and the resulting RNA is translated (the sequence of RNA is used to direct the assembly of a protein). Gene expression typically refers to the presence and rate of transcription. All organisms devote significant resources to the control of gene expression levels. Control of gene expression levels allows cells to respond appropriately to their environment by changing the ensemble of proteins. Understanding the details of how gene expression is controlled can also lead to improved biotechnology applicable to human health and crop production.

One way that gene expression is controlled is by very small RNAs that are not destined for translation. Instead, these 'microRNAs' function to seek out longer protein-coding RNAs, and target them for destruction and/or reductions in translation. microRNAs identify targets based on the same rules of nucleic acid base-pairing that hold together DNA structure. 'Perfect' complementarity, where all bases of the microRNA and the target are paired, are functional. Complete lack of complementarity of course is not functional. Between these two extremes lies a gray area. This project illuminated the 'gray area' by systematically testing the threshold of microRNA / target complementarity required for microRNA function in plants.

The major scientific results of the project were:

1. The development and testing of a novel experimental protocol for the assessment of microRNA function against varying complementarity with potential targets.

2. Use of the novel system to comprehensively test various patterns of microRNA / target complementarity for function.

3. Discovery of several 'rules' for microRNA targeting.

4. Discovery of some highly unusual patterns of microRNA targeting that expand knowledge of how microRNAs function.

Several scholarly articles describing the project's findings have been published. Two of the most important are freely available on line: http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/nar/gku157 and http://dx.doi.org/10.1105/tpc.113.120972. In addition, this project created two pieces of open-source software useful for other scientists studying microRNA function, 'GSTAr' and 'CleaveLand4'. Both of these are freely available online: https://github.com/MikeAxtell/CleaveLand4 and https://github.com/MikeAxtell/GSTAr. Vectors (short bits of recombinant DNA) that enable our novel experimental approach have been deposited to a public repository ('Addgene'), which enables other scientists to use our methods. This project contributed to the education of four Ph.D. students, including two who are members of groups currently under-represented in scientific careers. 

In broader terms, this project's results on microRNA functions provide important foundational knowledge that can be exploited in many biotechnological applications. Precision control of gene expression is a major goal of modern plant breeding approaches as well as biotechnology development. This project's careful description of the exact specificity parameters used by microRNAs will enable those approaches to crop improvement to be more effective and precise.
